title: The economy grew strongly last year, but hiring stagnated. It's making the gap between the rich and everyone else worse.
summary:
The data is in, and last year presents an economic conundrum: Overall growth was relatively strong, but job growth was virtually nonexistent.
ZipRecruiter economist Nicole Bachaud thinks the job market could be at a "pivot point" after stronger hiring in January.
They don't have to worry as much about rising prices of necessities and slowing wage growth.
"They're also enjoying faster wage growth, while lower-income families are seeing reduced wage growth, near-zero real wage growth, and not much wealth appreciation outside of real estate, if they have that."
Lower-income wage growth surged between 2021 and 2022, but has since cooled down a lot from the late 2022 peak.

title: Sorry, shoppers: prices aren't coming down post-tariffs ruling, Goldman Sachs says
summary:
Retail prices are unlikely to fall even after the Supreme Court struck down Trump's tariffs, Goldman Sachs says.

Impact LinkDon't expect prices at the store to fall just because the Supreme Court struck down President Donald Trump's tariffs.
But they're unlikely to cut prices outright, economists at Goldman Sachs wrote in a note published Sunday.

title: Job Searches Lengthen, Savings Dwindle for Americans
summary:
Joanelle Cobos (left), Clair Todd (right)Job searches are taking longer, and some Americans' savings aren't keeping up.
Wilke's experience underscores how quickly a prolonged job search can unravel someone's finances — especially for workers without much savings to fall back on.
Business Insider is speaking with workers who've found themselves at a corporate crossroads — whether due to a layoff, resignation, job search, or shifting workplace expectations.
Many Americans aren't prepared financially for unemploymentAs unemployment spells lengthen, the financial risks of a prolonged job search are rising for many Americans.
But if her job search stretches on, she knows that sense of security will gradually fade.

title: The mega-rich are moving. Here's where they're going.
summary:
In 2018, only 108,000 extremely wealthy individuals emigrated to a new country.
Switzerland, for example, has a lump-sum tax scheme that uses a taxpayer's lifestyle expenses as a surrogate tax base, rather than taxing global income and assets.
The UAE doesn't levy income tax; instead, it relies on a 5% value-added tax.
Many of the global wealthy are relocating to cities that offer entrepreneurial freedom, often lacking in more bureaucratic regions.
With growing restrictions on travel to many countries, wealthy individuals are applying for second residencies or even multiple citizenships as a safeguard.

title: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling Won’t Bring Car Prices Back to Earth
summary:
Now, despite a US Supreme Court ruling that will nix some of those Trump tariffs, car buyers will likely get no respite.
Automakers have actually done an OK job shielding consumers from the effects of tariffs, Caldwell says.
Even as retailers have blamed tariffs for steadily rising prices of consumer goods like electronics and appliances, car prices are up just 1 percent since this time last year, the firm’s data shows.
But as the tariff regime drags on, that could change in ways that make new-car buyers even less happy.
“If cost pressures continue to build, automakers may have less room to shield shoppers from higher prices,” Caldwell says, “but for now, the broader market impact is still playing out.”

"But this supreme court will find a way to come to the wrong conclusion, one that again will make China, and various other Nations, happy and rich.

title: COO's Jobs Are Especially Challenging Due to Tariff Uncertainty
summary:
Friday's tariff ruling has once again put America's supply-chain bosses in a bind.
"Tariffs are written in DC, and they're felt in the COO's inbox," Jason Schloetzer, a professor at Georgetown's McDonough School of Business, told Business Insider.
Many companies are still grappling with the impact of actions they took last year to cope with Trump's tariff hikes, said Rob Lalka, who teaches entrepreneurship at Tulane University.
Now, with the fate of Trump's tariffs up in the air, COOs are experiencing the kind of whiplash that can be debilitating, said Lalka, especially for those at startups and small businesses with limited resources.
Omni, which imports goods from Spain and exports to Canada, lost sales last year due to the Trump administration's tariffs, Smith said.
